Award.AwardTitle: A Quantum Hybrid System for Linking Rydberg Atom Quantum Gates
Award.AbstractNarration:
There has been significant progress constructing neutral atom quantum gates based on Rydberg atoms over the last year. These quantum gates are good candidates for building a scalable quantum computer because they possess the distinct advantage that the atomic ground states, where quantum information is stored, are weakly interacting while the Rydberg states, where gate operations are performed, are strongly interacting. These features make Rydberg atom quantum gates relatively immune to environmental noise and therefore show great promise as scalable systems for quantum devices. Theoretically, Rydberg atom ensembles can also be made to behave collectively as 'superatoms' using Rydberg atom dipole blockade to make Rydberg atom neutral quantum gates even more robust. One important element necessary to make Rydberg atom quantum gates useful and scalable is a way to transfer information between gates via the electromagnetic field. Our research focuses on developing this piece of the Rydberg atom quantum computation toolbox. We are investigating a new type of quantum hybrid system that can be used to transfer quantum information between 2 distinct clouds of Rydberg atoms. Rydberg atoms can interact strongly with surface polaritons and the surface polaritons can be used to transfer information between 2 distinct points in space. Surface polaritons are mixtures of crystal vibrations and light that can propagate along the surface of a dielectric solid, such as quartz.

The project will support 2 graduate students who will complete the work described. The research program will also enable undergraduate students to participate through the senior thesis and NSF-REU programs at OU. Our research group has been successful with undergraduate research participation as demonstrated by the completion of 31 different senior theses and NSF-REU projects over the last 10 years. To help recruit new students to and teach the students working on the project, the PI will include topics relevant to this research in the summer course in advanced research topics that he has taught in the past, interrupted only by a sabbatical, to faculty, graduate students and summer undergraduate research students, most recently at OU-Tulsa. Our work will also open, to our knowledge, an almost unexplored atom field interaction, that which occurs between Rydberg atoms and surface phonon polaritons. This area of research can contribute to a better understanding of surfaces and to the development of polaritronic devices. This is important because the frequencies spanned by polaritons are at the interface between photonic and electronic devices. This work will also help to develop readout schemes for other atomic based devices that can be integrated into atom chips and interfaced to conventional electronics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we investigated electric fields generated by the surfaces of materials. The electric fields are generated by surface adsorbates and elementary excitations of the surface itself, in our case, hybrid mixtures of vibrations and electro-magnetic fields. Electric fields created by surfaces are important to understand for applications in quantum engineering where the electric fields can lead to dephasing and shifting of the quantum states that are important to these applications becasue these effects can destroy important properties of the quantum states like entanglement. The method we used to measure the electric fields uses Rydberg atom electro-magnetically induced transparency imaging. The method is sensitive and linked to the properties of the atoms, therefore highly accurate. We observed unusually uniform electric fields on single crystal polished quartz samples. We also observed unusually small electric fields under conditions where slow electrons impinged on the surface. Our experiments suggest that small less than a single layer of uniformly distributed rubidium absorbates can turn the quartz surface into a negative electron affinity surface, allowing the binding of electrons in a 2-dimensional layer which cancels the electric field of the surface adsorbates. The 2-dimensional electron system shows promise as a platform for quantum information applications as it is similar to electrons on the surface of superfluid He, except the rubidium-quartz-electron system shows electron binding at much large temperatures, 300K vs <4 K. We also theorectically investigated the coupling of highly excited atoms to piezoelectric superlattices that support hybrid elementary excitations that are mixtures of vibrations and electro-magnetic waves. We showed that that some types of piezoelectric superlattices can support these types of excitations in frequency ranges that can resonantly interact with highly excited atoms. This work appeared in 7 publications and 9 international conference presentations.

During the course of this work, 1 graduate student earned their Ph.D. and another student earned a masters degree. 1 undergraduate student reseacher and 1 high school student worked on the project. 2 different postdocs helped to oversee the project and gained some leadership experience helping the PI manage the student projects. The students participated in special topics courses given by the PI over the summer on advanced topics relevant to the project. A journal club was also run for the students over the course of the academic year. The postdoc who worked on the project and has since moved on to their next position is now a junior facutly member working in a group in Germany. The undergraduate works at Boeing and the high school student  is  pursing a degree in physical science at a major research university.
